seriesJson.title: NER Washington Forum
seriesJson.description: Discussion series featuring a prominent figure affecting federal government policy.

node.title: FBI counterspy John Huminik
node.description: Former FBI counterspy John Huminik, author of Double Agent; for six years he worked as a double agent for the Soviet Union and the FBI

node.title: United Nations Ambassador Arthur Goldberg
node.description: United Nations Ambassador Arthur Goldberg, speaking at National Press Club on Vietnam, the Paris peace talks, the Middle East.

node.title: Press coverage of the Vietnam War
node.description: American Broadcasting Company News correspondent George Allen, on covering the war in Vietnam.

node.title: Challenge to the Warren Commission
node.description: A Challenge to the Warren Commission, part 2. New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison charges the U.S. government with concealing the truth about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy

node.title: Challenge to the Warren Commission, part one
node.description: A Challenge to the Warren Commission, part 1. New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison charges the U.S. government with concealing the truth about assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

node.title: UFOs and flying saucers
node.description: Stuart Nixon, of NICAP, the National Investigations Committee on Aerial Phenomena, about UFOs.

node.title: Muhammad Ali
node.description: Muhammad Ali discusses the draft, race relations, and the Muslim religion.

node.title: Filmmaker Felix Greene
node.description: British filmmaker Felix Greene discusses the film Inside North Vietnam, and American foreign policy in Southeast Asia.

node.title: Rev. Ralph Abernathy
node.description: Rev. Ralph Abernathy. His first major address since becoming leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), during Poor People's March on Washington, D.C.

node.title: Impact of the draft on colleges
node.description: Impact of the draft on colleges. The guest for this program is United States Representative Edith Green, D-Oregon.

node.title: Dr. Werner Von Braun
node.description: 10th anniversary of United States space exploration. On Jan. 31, 1958, Explorer I was launched. Developers included Dr. Werner Von Braun and Dr. William Pickering, who speak to National Press Club in this recording.

node.title: Congressional Quarterly editors
node.description: Editors from Congressional Quarterly assess the 90th Congress of the United States.

node.title: Rev. William Sloane Coffin and Ossie Davis
node.description: Reverend William Sloane Coffin, Yale University chaplain who had been indicted for counseling young men to resist the draft; and actor Ossie Davis. Both discuss antiwar mobilization in Washington, D.C.

node.title: Teacher Corps
node.description: Richard Graham, director, National Teacher Corps, on educating poverty-stricken children.

node.title: Antiwar protestor Matthew Clark
node.description: Matthew Clark, 19 year old draft resister and organizer of The Resistance, an antiwar organization. View of a war protestor. Part 4 of 4: War in Vietnam.

node.title: Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman
node.description: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Orville Freeman.

node.title: Crime in America
node.description: Hon. Luther Youngdahl, Senior United States District Court Judge for District of Columbia, on Crime in America: A View from the Bench.

node.title: Strom Thurmond
node.description: United States Senatory Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., with a "hawk's view." Part 3 of 4: War in Vietnam

node.title: Antiwar protestor Gary Rader
node.description: Former Army Special Forces member Gary Rader, a former Green Beret, discusses his antiwar activism. Part 2 of 4: War in Vietnam.

node.title: General William C. Westmoreland
node.description: United States Army General William C. Westmoreland, commander, American troops in Vietnam. Part 1 of 4: War in Vietnam. Westmoreland: "The enemy's hopes are dim."

node.title: Urban problems
node.description: Irving Hand, president, American Institute of Planners and executive director, Pennsylvania State Planning Board, on urban problems in America.

node.title: Dr. Gunnar Myrdahl
node.description: Dr. Gunnar Myrdal, sociologist, on the fate of cities: urban problems, race relations, civil strife.

node.title: Columnist Robert Novak
node.description: Columnist Robert Novak, about President Lyndon Johnson's decline in popularity.

node.title: Crime in America
node.description: United States Representative Richard H. Poth (R-Va.), chair, Republican Task Force on Crime, on crime in America.

node.title: Abortion, part 2
node.description: Report on international conference on abortion, held in Washington, D.C. Guests are: Dr. Carl Kaysen, director, Institute for Advanced Studies, Princeton, NJ.; and Dr. Andre Hellegers, Georgetown University School of Medicine.

node.title: Abortion, part 1
node.description: Report on international conference on abortion, held in Washington, D.C. Guests are: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, Executive Vice President, Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr., Foundation, and Dean Bayliss Manning, Stanford University School of Law.

node.title: National economy
node.description: Discussion on state of national economy and status of President Lyndon Johnson's proposed tax surcharge bill. The guest for this program is Gardner Ackley, chairman, President's Council of Economic Advisors.

node.title: Vice President Hubert Humphrey
node.description: Vice President Hubert Humphrey, speaking about the President's Council on Youth Opportunity. He refers to hippies and the youth movement.

node.title: Problems facing American Indians
node.description: This program focuses on problems facing Native Americans and the  government efforts to solve those problems. Guest: Robert L. Bennett, United States Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

node.title: A U.S. Constitutional Convention?, part 2
node.description: Proposed United States Constitutional Convention. Guest: United States Senator Joseph Tydings, D-Maryland.

node.title: A U.S. Constitutional Convention?, part 1
node.description: Proposed United States Constitutional Convention. Guest: United States Senator Everett Dirksen, R-Illinois, and Senate Minority Leader.

node.title: Presidency and the Press
node.description: The Presidency and the Press. Guest: George Christian, press secretary to President Johnson and successor to Bill Moyers.

node.title: Comedian Mort Sahl
node.description: Comedian and political satirist Mort Sahl.

node.title: Rodent extermination
node.description: United States Representative Martha Griffiths, D-Michigan, on legislative action regarding rodent extermination in the United States.

node.title: Police riot control training, part 2
node.description: This program, the second of two parts, focuses on police riot control training at Fairfax County, Virginia, near Washington, D.C.

node.title: Police riot control training, part 1
node.description: This program, the first of two parts, focuses on police riot control training at Fairfax County, Virginia, near Washington, D.C.

node.title: Race relations in the United States
node.description: The guest for this program is Dr. Nathan Hare, African-American sociologist.

node.title: Anti-riot legislation
node.description: Anti-riot legislation and the growing trend toward lawlessness in the United States. Guest: United States Representative Dan Kuykendall, R-Tennessee.

node.title: New role of freshmen Congressmen
node.description: The New Role of Freshmen Congressmen, in the 90th Congress. Guests: United States Representative Howard W. Pollock, R-Alaska; United States Representative Jerry L. Pettis, R-California.

node.title: Vietnam War: Field General's view
node.description: The Vietnam War: A Field General's View. Guest: United States Marine Corps General Lewis Walt, immediate past commander of Marine forces in Vietnam.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967
node.description: House hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Includes: United States Representative Claude Pepper (D-Florida); Thomas Hoving; Frank Stanton; McGeorge Bundy; Fred Friendly; and Jerrold Sandler.

node.title: Agriculture issues
node.description: Agriculture Issues and Problems at Home and Abroad. Guest: United States Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman.

node.title: Role of women in government
node.description: Guests are United States Representative Charlotte T. Reid, R-Illinois.

node.title: Election campaign reform, part 2
node.description: This program focuses on election campaign reform. United States Senator James B. Pearson, R-Kansas.

node.title: Election campaign reform, part 1
node.description: This program focuses on election campaign reform. Guests are United States Senator Robert F. Kennedy, D-New York; United States Senator Everett Dirksen, R-Illinois.

node.title: White House Fellows program
node.description: Thomas Carr, director of President's Commission on White House Fellows.

node.title: Veterans' home mortgage fraud
node.description: Home mortgage fraud affecting military veterans. Guests are United States Representative Charles E. Bennett (D-Florida); and Harry D. Dodson of the Veterans Administration.

node.title: Atomic Energy Commission Chairman Glenn T. Seaborg
node.description: Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) Chairman Glenn T. Seaborg on the role of atomic or nuclear energy.

node.title: Farris Bryant
node.description: Hon. Farris Bryant, chairman, President's Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.

node.title: Vice President Hubert Humphrey
node.description: Vice President Hubert Humphrey, meeting with British students in London.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part six
node.description: Discussion of Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 and a Ford Foundation report, "The Hidden Medium." Guests: Jerrold Sandler, executive director, National Educational Radio Network, and Herman W. Land, consultant.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part five
node.description: Senate hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony of Dr. Frank Stanton, president of CBS, announcing $1 million gift to newly-chartered Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part four
node.description: Senate hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony of Jerrold Sandler, executive director, National Educational Radio Network.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part three
node.description: Senate hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony including George Baird, director of education for South Carolina Educational Television Network.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part two
node.description: This program, the second of six, explores the Senate hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony includes Dr. James Killian, who cites differences between Ford Foundation and Carnegie Commission proposals.

node.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part one
node.description: This program, the first of six, explores the Senate Hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony before the U.S. Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Communications, chaired by Senator John Pastore.

node.title: Ralph Nader
node.description: Ralph Nader discusses automobile design and safety.

node.title: American Dairy Farmers bill
node.description: Representative B.F. Sisk discusses the American Dairy Farmers Bill and aid to farmers.

node.title: Congressional ethics
node.description: Congressman Wayne Hays of Ohio discusses the question of Congressional ethics.
